description: From Middle English mirour, from Old French mireor (“mirror”, literally “looker, watcher”), from mirer (“look at”), from Latin mīror (“wonder at”), from mīrus (“wonderful”), from Proto-Indo-European *smey- (“to laugh, to be glad”). Displaced native Old English sċēawere (literally “watcher”), which was also the word for "spy."

entries.meaning: A smooth surface, usually made of glass with reflective material painted on the underside, that reflects light so as to give an image of what is in front of it.
examples: I had a look in the mirror to see if the blood had come off my face.
We could see the lorry in the mirror, so decided to change lanes.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) An object, person, or event that reflects or gives a picture of another.
examples: His story is a mirror into the life of orphans growing up.

entries.meaning: (computing, Internet) A disk, website or other resource that contains replicated data.
examples: Although the content had been deleted from his blog, it was still found on some mirrors.

entries.meaning: (historical) A kind of political self-help book, advising kings, princes, etc. on how to behave.

verbs.description: mirror (third-person singular simple present mirrors, present participle mirroring, simple past and past participle mirrored)

entries.meaning: (transitive) Of an event, activity, behaviour, etc, to be identical to; to be a copy of.
examples: He tried to mirror Elvis's life. He copied his fashion and his mannerisms, and he even went to live in Graceland.

entries.meaning: (computing, transitive) To create something identical to (a web site, etc.).
(transitive) To reflect, as in a mirror.
